sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to Unit 28 of our English learning journey. In this unit, we'll explore the use of 'must' and 'can't'

sections.title: Definition
sections.content: to express certainty, obligation, and deduction. Let's delve into the key concepts.

sections.title: 'Must' for Certainty and Deduction
sections.content: Use 'must' to express strong certainty about a present situation or a deduction about the past.
points: He must be at home; his car is in the driveway
She must know the answer; she's an expert in this field

sections.title: 'Can’t' for Certainty and Deduction
sections.content: Use 'can't' to express strong certainty that something is not true or a deduction about the past.
points: It can't be true; I just spoke to him yesterday
She can't have forgotten her keys; she's usually very careful

sections.title: Examples
sections.content: Let's examine examples to illustrate the application of 'must' and 'can't':
points: You must be joking; that can't be true.
She must be at the office; her car is in the parking lot
He can't have finished the project already; it's too complex

sections.title: Common Mistakes
sections.content: Address common mistakes related to the use of 'must' and 'can't' in certain contexts.
points: Incorrect:He can't have at the party last night
Correct: 'He can't have been at the party last night.

sections.title: Recap and Summary:
sections.content: In summary, 'must' and 'can't' are used to express certainty and deductions in various situations. Pay attention to the nuances of each in different contexts.

sections.title: Additional Resources:
sections.content: For additional practice and reinforcement, consider exploring examples in language learning books and online exercises.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Thank you for joining today's lesson on 'Must and Can't.' Practice using these expressions to convey certainty and deductions effectively, and feel free to reach out if you have any questions. Happy learning!
